title: 2 Samuel Chapter 5 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 2 Samuel chapter 5 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 2 Samuel Chapter 5 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 2 Samuel Chapter 5.

questions.question: Who came to David in Hebron and said, 'Behold, we are thy bone and thy flesh'?
questions.correctAnswer: All the tribes of Israel
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 5:1 states that all the tribes of Israel came to David in Hebron and spoke these words.

questions.question: According to 2 Samuel 5:2, who was king before David?
questions.correctAnswer: Saul
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 5:2 refers to Saul as the king over Israel before David.

questions.question: Where did David reign over Judah for seven years and six months?
questions.correctAnswer: Hebron
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 5:5 states that David reigned in Hebron over Judah for seven years and six months.

questions.question: How old was David when he began to reign?
questions.correctAnswer: Thirty years old
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 5:4 states that David was thirty years old when he began to reign.

questions.question: What did David call the stronghold he took from the Jebusites?
questions.correctAnswer: The city of David
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 5:7 states that David took the stronghold of Zion and called it the city of David.

questions.question: What did David say about those who would attack the Jebusites by the gutter?
options: They shall be chief and captain
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be chief and captain
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 5:8 records David saying whoever attacks by the gutter and smites the Jebusites shall be chief and captain.

questions.question: Who sent messengers to David with cedar trees, carpenters, and masons to build him a house?
questions.correctAnswer: Hiram king of Tyre
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 5:11 states that Hiram king of Tyre sent these materials and craftsmen to David.

questions.question: After coming from Hebron, what did David do regarding his family?
questions.correctAnswer: Took more concubines and wives
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 5:13 explains that David took more concubines and wives after coming from Hebron.

questions.question: Which of these is NOT listed as one of David's sons born in Jerusalem?
questions.correctAnswer: Absalom
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 5:14-16 lists David's sons born in Jerusalem; Absalom is not among them listed here.

questions.question: Where did the Philistines spread themselves when they came to fight David?
questions.correctAnswer: The valley of Rephaim
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 5:18 states the Philistines spread themselves in the valley of Rephaim.

questions.question: True or False: David defeated the Philistines at Baalperazim because the LORD delivered them into his hand.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 5:19-20 shows David asking the LORD if he should go to the Philistines and the LORD promising victory, which David achieved at Baalperazim.

questions.question: True or False: The Jebusites believed David could easily enter their city.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 5:6 reveals the Jebusites thought David could not come in, saying he could not enter except he took away the blind and lame.

questions.question: True or False: David enquired of the LORD before fighting the Philistines the second time.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 5:23 shows David enquiring of the LORD again before the second battle with the Philistines.

questions.question: Complete this verse from 2 Samuel 5:20: 'The LORD hath broken forth upon mine enemies before me, as the breach of ______.'
questions.correctAnswer: waters
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 5:20 states the LORD broke forth upon David's enemies as the breach of waters.

questions.question: What was the instruction the LORD gave David about attacking the Philistines the second time?
options: Come upon them behind and wait for the sound in the tops of the mulberry trees
Wait until they leave the valley of Rephaim
questions.correctAnswer: Come upon them behind and wait for the sound in the tops of the mulberry trees
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 5:23-24 details God's command to David to compass behind the Philistines and attack when he hears the sound in the mulberry trees.

medium.title: 2 Samuel Chapter 5 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 2 Samuel Chapter 5 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with trusting God in leadership decisions. Based on 2 Samuel 5, what biblical truth would you share?
options: God establishes and exalts leaders for His people’s sake.
Leaders must rely solely on their own wisdom.
Success depends only on human strength and strategy.
Leadership is based on popularity among people.
questions.correctAnswer: God establishes and exalts leaders for His people’s sake.
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 5:12 shows David recognizing that the LORD had established him king and exalted his kingdom for Israel’s sake, teaching us to trust God’s sovereign hand in leadership.

questions.question: How does 2 Samuel 5 teach us about seeking God’s guidance in difficult situations?
options: David inquired of the LORD before going into battle against the Philistines.
David acted impulsively without consulting God.
David sought advice only from military commanders.
David avoided conflict to keep peace.
questions.correctAnswer: David inquired of the LORD before going into battle against the Philistines.
questions.explanation: Verses 19, 23, and 24 show David seeking God’s direction before engaging the Philistines, teaching us to depend on God’s guidance in trials.

questions.question: A believer is facing opposition in their work. How does David’s example in taking Jerusalem from the Jebusites encourage perseverance?
options: David trusted God and took the stronghold despite the enemy’s confidence.
David avoided the challenge to keep safe.
David surrendered to the enemy’s threats.
David relied only on his soldiers’ strength.
questions.correctAnswer: David trusted God and took the stronghold despite the enemy’s confidence.
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 5:6-7 shows the Jebusites mocking David’s attempt, but he trusted God and captured the city, encouraging believers to persevere with faith.

questions.question: What does 2 Samuel 5 teach about humility and acknowledging God’s role in success?
options: David acknowledged the LORD God of hosts was with him as he grew great.
David claimed all success as his own doing.
David boasted before his people about his victories.
David ignored God’s help in his reign.
questions.correctAnswer: David acknowledged the LORD God of hosts was with him as he grew great.
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 5:10 highlights David’s recognition that his growing success was due to God’s presence, teaching humility and gratitude.

questions.question: How does 2 Samuel 5 illustrate the importance of prayer and obedience in spiritual warfare?
options: David obeyed God’s instructions and attacked when he heard the sound in the mulberry trees.
David ignored God’s commands and charged recklessly.
David relied on his army’s size alone.
David tried to negotiate peace without prayer.
questions.correctAnswer: David obeyed God’s instructions and attacked when he heard the sound in the mulberry trees.
questions.explanation: Verses 23-25 show David following God’s precise guidance in battle, exemplifying the power of prayer and obedience in spiritual challenges.

questions.question: A young Christian asks about God’s care for His people. What does 2 Samuel 5:2 teach about God’s role in leadership and care?
options: God said David shall feed and be captain over His people Israel.
God left Israel without a shepherd.
God chose Saul to always remain king.
God told David to rule only over Judah.
questions.correctAnswer: God said David shall feed and be captain over His people Israel.
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 5:2 emphasizes God’s directive for David to shepherd His people, illustrating God’s providential care through appointed leaders.

questions.question: What practical lesson on family life and stewardship can be learned from David’s growing household in Jerusalem?
options: David expanded his family with more wives and children, acknowledging God’s blessing on his household.
David neglected his family after becoming king.
David separated from his family to focus only on the throne.
questions.correctAnswer: David expanded his family with more wives and children, acknowledging God’s blessing on his household.
questions.explanation: Verses 13-16 show David taking more wives and having children, reflecting biblical principles of family growth and stewardship.

questions.question: True or False: According to 2 Samuel 5, David was thirty years old when he began to reign and reigned for forty years.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 5:4 states David was thirty when he began to reign and ruled for forty years, showing God’s timing in leadership.

questions.question: True or False: The Philistines ceased their attacks on David after his first victory.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 5:22 shows that the Philistines came up again, indicating ongoing challenges and the need for continual reliance on God.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: David called the place where he defeated the Philistines '____' because the LORD broke forth upon his enemies like a breach of waters.
questions.correctAnswer: Baalperazim
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 5:20 records David naming the battlefield Baalperazim to commemorate God’s powerful intervention.

questions.question: How does David’s response to the Jebusites’ taunt teach us about overcoming discouragement?
options: David ignored their insults and confidently took the city.
David retreated and gave up the fight.
David negotiated a peace treaty out of fear.
David promised not to attack the city.
questions.correctAnswer: David ignored their insults and confidently took the city.
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 5:6-7 shows David’s faith and courage despite the Jebusites’ mocking, encouraging believers to trust God and persevere.

questions.question: What does the alliance between David and Hiram king of Tyre teach about Christian fellowship and cooperation?
options: David received help in building his house, showing the value of partnerships.
questions.correctAnswer: David received help in building his house, showing the value of partnerships.
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 5:11 illustrates cooperation and fellowship in accomplishing God’s purposes.

questions.question: How does David’s action of burning the Philistine images reflect biblical principles about purity and worship?
options: David destroyed idols, showing rejection of false worship.
David kept the idols as trophies.
David ignored the idols and left them intact.
questions.correctAnswer: David destroyed idols, showing rejection of false worship.
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 5:21 shows David and his men burning the images, demonstrating faithfulness to God and cleansing from idolatry.

questions.question: How does David’s formation of a league with the elders before the LORD teach us about seeking God’s blessing in communal decisions?
options: David made a covenant in God’s presence, emphasizing spiritual unity and accountability.
David made decisions without consulting others.
David relied only on political power.
David avoided involving God in leadership.
questions.correctAnswer: David made a covenant in God’s presence, emphasizing spiritual unity and accountability.
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 5:3 shows David’s humility and desire for God’s blessing in leadership.

questions.question: What does David’s example in 2 Samuel 5 teach about the importance of integrity in leadership and warfare?
options: David sought God’s guidance and acted according to His commands, showing integrity.
David used deceit and trickery to win battles.
David ignored God’s will for his own gain.
David acted selfishly without concern for God’s honor.
questions.correctAnswer: David sought God’s guidance and acted according to His commands, showing integrity.
questions.explanation: Verses 19-25 demonstrate David’s consistent dependence on God and obedience, key to godly leadership.

hard.title: 2 Samuel Chapter 5 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 2 Samuel Chapter 5.

questions.question: What phrase did the tribes of Israel use to express their kinship with David when they came to Hebron?
options: Thou art our shepherd and king
We are thy bone and thy flesh
questions.correctAnswer: We are thy bone and thy flesh
questions.explanation: In 2 Samuel 5:1, the tribes of Israel say to David, "Behold, we are thy bone and thy flesh," expressing their close kinship and unity with him.

questions.question: According to 2 Samuel 5:2, what role did the LORD assign to David over Israel?
questions.correctAnswer: Captain over Israel
questions.explanation: The LORD told David, "Thou shalt feed my people Israel, and thou shalt be a captain over Israel," highlighting his role as leader and shepherd of the nation (2 Samuel 5:2).

questions.question: How long did David reign over Judah in Hebron before ruling all Israel and Judah from Jerusalem?
questions.correctAnswer: Seven years and six months
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 5:5 states that David reigned over Judah in Hebron for seven years and six months before reigning over all Israel and Judah in Jerusalem for thirty-three years.

questions.question: What was the name of the city David captured from the Jebusites, which later became known as the City of David?
questions.correctAnswer: Zion
questions.explanation: David took the stronghold of Zion, which was the city of David, as mentioned in 2 Samuel 5:7; this site later became central to Israel's capital.

questions.question: In 2 Samuel 5:8, David made a statement about those who would be chief and captain in the city. What physical conditions did he mention as being despised?
questions.correctAnswer: The blind and the lame
questions.explanation: David declared that whoever smote the Jebusites including the blind and the lame, whom he hated, would be chief and captain (2 Samuel 5:8).

questions.question: What kind of building materials and workers did Hiram king of Tyre send to David to build him a house?
questions.correctAnswer: Cedar trees, carpenters, and masons
questions.explanation: Hiram sent cedar trees along with carpenters and masons to build David's house, reflecting the alliance and the cultural exchange between Tyre and Israel (2 Samuel 5:11).

questions.question: How does the theme of divine establishment of kingship in 2 Samuel 5:12 connect with the broader biblical motif of God's sovereign choice?
options: It shows that kingship depends on military strength
It emphasizes human wisdom in leadership
It underlines God's role in raising leaders for His people
It promotes democratic election of kings
questions.correctAnswer: It underlines God's role in raising leaders for His people
questions.explanation: David recognized that the LORD had established him king and exalted his kingdom for Israel's sake, emphasizing God's sovereign role in leadership (2 Samuel 5:12), a recurring biblical theme.

questions.question: Which of the following sons was NOT listed as born to David in Jerusalem according to 2 Samuel 5:14-16?
questions.correctAnswer: Nahash
questions.explanation: The sons listed in 2 Samuel 5:14-16 include Shammua, Shobab, Nathan, Solomon, and others, but Nahash is not mentioned among David's sons here.

questions.question: What strategic military advice did the LORD give David when the Philistines spread themselves in the valley of Rephaim the second time?
options: Come upon them over against the mulberry trees
questions.correctAnswer: Come upon them over against the mulberry trees
questions.explanation: In 2 Samuel 5:23, the LORD instructed David not to attack directly but to come upon the Philistines over against the mulberry trees, indicating a tactical ambush.

questions.question: What was the significance of the sound of 'going in the tops of the mulberry trees' according to the LORD's instruction to David?
options: It signaled the arrival of reinforcements
It was a sign to bestir himself for battle
It meant the Philistines were retreating
It indicated the end of the battle
questions.correctAnswer: It was a sign to bestir himself for battle
questions.explanation: The LORD said that when David heard the sound in the tops of the mulberry trees, he should bestir himself because the LORD would go out before him to smite the Philistine host (2 Samuel 5:24).

questions.question: What does the naming of the place Baalperazim in 2 Samuel 5:20 symbolize in the context of Israel's victory over the Philistines?
options: A place of peace and rest
The breach or bursting forth of God's power
questions.correctAnswer: The breach or bursting forth of God's power
questions.explanation: David called the place Baalperazim, meaning 'the LORD hath broken forth,' symbolizing God's powerful intervention and victory over his enemies (2 Samuel 5:20).

questions.question: What did David and his men do to the images left by the Philistines after the battle at Baalperazim?
options: They returned them to the Philistines
They melted them down for metal
questions.correctAnswer: They burned them
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 5:21 states that David and his men burned the images left by the Philistines, demonstrating a rejection of idolatry and asserting Israel's covenant faithfulness.

questions.question: True or False: David inquired of the LORD both before the first and second battles against the Philistines in the valley of Rephaim.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: David inquired of the LORD before the initial attack (2 Samuel 5:19) and again before the second battle (2 Samuel 5:23), showing his dependence on divine guidance.

questions.question: David's reign began at age 30 and lasted 40 years. How does this chronological detail contribute to understanding his significance in biblical history?
options: It shows he was the youngest king ever
It aligns with prophetic expectations of a messianic king
It emphasizes the brevity of his reign
It is a symbolic number with no historical value
questions.correctAnswer: It aligns with prophetic expectations of a messianic king
questions.explanation: David reigning 40 years starting at 30 (2 Samuel 5:4) aligns with biblical symbolism of a full, divinely appointed reign, foreshadowing the Messiah from his lineage.

questions.question: How does David's building of the city walls 'from Millo and inward' (2 Samuel 5:9) reflect the ancient Near Eastern practice of urban fortification?
options: Indicates defensive consolidation of the city
Shows a decline in the city's importance
Is a metaphor for spiritual protection
questions.correctAnswer: Indicates defensive consolidation of the city
questions.explanation: Building around Millo and inward (2 Samuel 5:9) reflects ancient Near Eastern strategies for fortifying cities, securing political and military control.

theological.title: 2 Samuel Chapter 5 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 2 Samuel Chapter 5 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What significant theological truth is expressed when the tribes of Israel say to David, 'Behold, we are thy bone and thy flesh'?
options: They acknowledge a deep covenantal and familial unity with David
They claim David is their biological father
questions.correctAnswer: They acknowledge a deep covenantal and familial unity with David
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 5:1 shows the tribes recognizing their unity with David as kin, which echoes the biblical theme of God's covenant people being one body (Ephesians 2:19-22; Genesis 29:14; 1 Corinthians 12:12-27; John 15:5).

questions.question: How does 2 Samuel 5:2 describe David’s divine appointment as king?
options: The LORD said to David, 'Thou shalt feed my people Israel, and thou shalt be a captain over Israel'
David declared himself king by force
The people elected David without divine guidance
Saul anointed David before his death
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD said to David, 'Thou shalt feed my people Israel, and thou shalt be a captain over Israel'
questions.explanation: This verse reveals God's sovereign calling and commissioning of David as shepherd and leader, reflecting the biblical motif of God as the ultimate king who appoints earthly rulers (Psalm 78:70-72; Ezekiel 34:23-24; John 10:11; Acts 13:22).

questions.question: What is the significance of the elders anointing David king over Israel as recorded in 2 Samuel 5:3?
options: It symbolizes God's approval and the people's acceptance of David’s kingship
It was a political alliance without spiritual meaning
It was done without the LORD's blessing
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes God's approval and the people's acceptance of David’s kingship
questions.explanation: Anointing signifies divine election and public acknowledgment, a practice rooted in Israel’s monarchy (1 Samuel 16:13; 1 Kings 1:39; Psalm 2:6; Isaiah 61:1-3), confirming David’s God-ordained role.

questions.question: David began to reign at what age and for how long did he reign according to 2 Samuel 5:4?
options: Thirty years old; reigned forty years
Twenty years old; reigned thirty years
Forty years old; reigned twenty years
Fifteen years old; reigned fifty years
questions.correctAnswer: Thirty years old; reigned forty years
questions.explanation: This highlights God’s providential timing in leadership (Ecclesiastes 3:1; Psalm 90:12; 1 Kings 2:11; Luke 3:23), emphasizing maturity and divine sovereignty in David's reign.

questions.question: What strategic city did David capture that became known as 'the city of David'?
questions.correctAnswer: Zion, the stronghold of Jerusalem
questions.explanation: David's capture of Zion fulfills God’s plan to establish the capital and spiritual center (2 Samuel 5:7-9; Psalm 48:2; Isaiah 60:14; Zechariah 8:3), underscoring God’s control over history and covenantal promises.

questions.question: Why did the Jebusites mock David with the words 'Except thou take away the blind and the lame, thou shalt not come in hither'?
options: They believed Jerusalem was impregnable to David’s forces
They were warning David of a plague
They sought to surrender without a fight
questions.correctAnswer: They believed Jerusalem was impregnable to David’s forces
questions.explanation: This reflects human arrogance and underestimation of God’s power (2 Samuel 5:6-8; Proverbs 16:18; Isaiah 10:5-7; Jeremiah 9:23-24; Romans 8:31), showing that God’s strength surpasses human limitations.

questions.question: What does David’s inquiry of the LORD before battle against the Philistines demonstrate about his leadership?
options: Dependence on divine guidance for victory
questions.correctAnswer: Dependence on divine guidance for victory
questions.explanation: David’s seeking God’s counsel (2 Samuel 5:19, 23-24) exemplifies godly leadership centered on the sovereignty of God (Exodus 17:11-12; Judges 7:2-7; Proverbs 3:5-6; James 1:5), affirming that true success comes from God.

questions.question: What theological truth is highlighted by the LORD’s assurance to David: 'I will doubtless deliver the Philistines into thine hand'?
options: God’s sovereign control over history and battles
David’s personal strength is the cause of victory
questions.correctAnswer: God’s sovereign control over history and battles
questions.explanation: This underscores God's providence and power over nations (2 Samuel 5:19; Exodus 14:14; Psalm 44:3; Isaiah 41:10; Romans 8:28), affirming trust in divine deliverance rather than human might.

questions.question: The burning of the Philistine images after their defeat symbolizes what important biblical principle?
options: The rejection and destruction of idolatry
A political alliance with the Philistines
questions.correctAnswer: The rejection and destruction of idolatry
questions.explanation: Destroying idols reflects God’s holiness and hatred of idolatry (2 Samuel 5:21; Exodus 20:3-5; Deuteronomy 7:25-26; Isaiah 42:8; 1 Corinthians 10:14), teaching the necessity of exclusive devotion to God.

questions.question: What does the alliance between King Hiram of Tyre and David, involving cedar trees and craftsmen, indicate about David’s reign?
options: Recognition and support from neighboring kingdoms
questions.correctAnswer: Recognition and support from neighboring kingdoms
questions.explanation: This alliance shows God’s blessing on David’s kingdom and the establishment of peaceful relations (2 Samuel 5:11; 1 Kings 5:1-12; Psalm 72:8-11; Isaiah 2:2-4; Romans 13:1), demonstrating God’s providential ordering of nations.

questions.question: How does 2 Samuel 5:12 reveal David’s understanding of his kingship?
options: He perceives that God established and exalted his kingdom for Israel's sake
He claims his kingdom is by his own power
He intends to rule independently of God
He doubts God’s blessing on his reign
questions.correctAnswer: He perceives that God established and exalted his kingdom for Israel's sake
questions.explanation: David recognizes God’s sovereign election and faithfulness to His covenant people (2 Samuel 5:12; Psalm 89:20-37; 1 Chronicles 17:11-14; Romans 9:17-18; Acts 13:22), emphasizing divine grace in leadership.

questions.question: What is the theological significance of David’s multiple wives and concubines bearing him sons and daughters in Jerusalem?
options: It reflects the continuation of David’s lineage, including the messianic line
It shows David’s rejection of God’s law
It was unique to David and not accepted in Israel
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects the continuation of David’s lineage, including the messianic line
questions.explanation: The offspring signify God’s covenant promise of a lasting dynasty culminating in the Messiah (2 Samuel 5:13-16; 2 Samuel 7:12-16; Psalm 89:3-4; Luke 1:32-33; Hebrews 7:14), underscoring God’s redemptive plan through David’s house.

questions.question: What does the name 'Baalperazim,' given by David to the place of his victory, signify theologically?
options: 'The LORD hath broken forth upon mine enemies before me, as the breach of waters'
The place where David was defeated
questions.correctAnswer: 'The LORD hath broken forth upon mine enemies before me, as the breach of waters'
questions.explanation: The name declares God's powerful intervention and triumph over enemies (2 Samuel 5:20; Exodus 14:21-22; Psalm 18:16-17; Isaiah 59:19; Revelation 19:11), affirming God as the ultimate warrior on behalf of His people.

questions.question: What instruction did God give David about attacking the Philistines the second time, according to 2 Samuel 5:23-24?
options: Do not attack directly; instead, circle behind and wait for the sound in the mulberry trees
questions.correctAnswer: Do not attack directly; instead, circle behind and wait for the sound in the mulberry trees
questions.explanation: God’s tactical guidance shows divine strategy and timing (2 Samuel 5:23-24; Exodus 17:8-13; Judges 7:15-22; Proverbs 16:33; Ecclesiastes 3:1), emphasizing obedience and reliance on God’s direction.

questions.question: The final verse 2 Samuel 5:25 mentions David striking the Philistines from Geba to Gazer. What does this convey about God’s promises to His anointed king?
options: God grants comprehensive victory and expands David’s kingdom
David wins only a minor skirmish
David’s victory is only partial and temporary
questions.correctAnswer: God grants comprehensive victory and expands David’s kingdom
questions.explanation: This demonstrates God’s faithfulness to His covenant promises of protection and dominion for His chosen king (2 Samuel 5:25; Psalm 2:6-9; Isaiah 9:6-7; Luke 1:32-33; Revelation 11:15), illustrating the unfolding messianic reign.
